elements.content: Ten coordination polymers, [Mn9(L1)8(OH)2(H2O)21] n (1), [Mn3.5(L1)3(OH)(H2O)8] n (2), [Cu(L1)(H2O)1.375] n (3), {Zn(L1)(DMF)[(CH3)2NH]0.25} n (4), [Zn2(L1)2(4,4′-bipy)(DMF)0.5(H2O)0.5] n (5), [Zn2(L1)2(bib)(H2O)6.75] n (6), [Cd2(L1)2(H2O)7.5] n (7), [Cd2(L1)2(H2O)7.5] n (8), [Cd(L1)(bpp)] n (9), and [Cd2(L1)2(bib)(H2O)6] n (10) (L1 = 4-amino-3,5-bis(3-carboxyphenyl)-1,2,4-triazole, bib = 1,4-bis(imidazol)butane, bpp = 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)propane), have been prepared and structurally characterized. In these compounds, L1 exhibits different coordination modes and conformations, constructing various architectures by bridging a variety of building units and adjusting the roles of different organic bases. Compound 1 presents a 3D diamond topology built by bridging rare Mn9 clusters with L1. Compound 2 is a 1D chain structure. Compound 3 shows a unique 2D {42.6}2{44.69.82} topology by linking paddle-wheel SBU with L1. Compound 4 is a 1D double chain structure. Compound 5 presents an unusual 2D V2O5 net with {42.63.8}{42.6} topology by linking 4,4′-bipy with the double chains constructed by L1 and Zn(II) atoms. Compound 6 exhibits a rare 3D coe topology with point (Schlafli) symbol for net: {42.6.102.12}{42.6}. Compound 7 presents an unusual 1D strap shaped structure. Compound 8 is a zero-periodic structure. Compound 9 shows an interesting 4-connected 2D interpenetrating net with point (Schlafli) symbol {44.62}. Compound 10 is a 1D “H” shaped structure when it is viewed from the c axis direction. The luminescent properties of compounds 4−7 and 9, and the magnetic properties of compound 1 have been investigated in the solid state.

elements.content: A series of coordination polymers, featuring from 1D to 3D structure, have been constructed based on the reaction of 4-amino-3,5-bis(3-carboxyphenyl)-1,2,4-triazole ligand with different metals and by adjusting the roles of different organic bases.
elements.clean_text: A series of coordination polymers, featuring from 1D to 3D structure, have been constructed based on the reaction of 4-amino-3,5-bis(3-carboxyphenyl)-1,2,4-triazole ligand with different metals and by adjusting the roles of different organic bases.

elements.content: The design and construction of coordination polymers is a fascinating area because of their interesting molecular topologies and potential applications such as gas adsorption and separation, luminescent sensors, molecule magnets, and catalysts. To date, a large number of coordination polymers with interesting and complicated architectures and topologies have been synthesized successfully. The “network topological approach” is an important and essential aspect of the analysis, comparison, and design of coordination polymers by reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets in which the metal ions generally serve as nodes while the ligands act as linkers. Therefore, the rational design of suitable ligands (linkers) is most critical, which can extend the metal ions or secondary building units (SBUs) in a predetermined fashion to produce target network-based materials with specific structures and properties. In this regard, even the minor structural change of ligand such as the angle, distance, and relative orientation of the donor or functional groups can result in the variation of coordination framework.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The design and construction of coordination polymers is a fascinating area because of their interesting molecular topologies and potential applications such as gas adsorption and separation, luminescent sensors, molecule magnets, and catalysts. To date, a large number of coordination polymers with interesting and complicated architectures and topologies have been synthesized successfully. The "network topological approach" is an important and essential aspect of the analysis, comparison, and design of coordination polymers by reducing multidimensional structures to simple node-and-linker nets in which the metal ions generally serve as nodes while the ligands act as linkers. Therefore, the rational design of suitable ligands (linkers) is most critical, which can extend the metal ions or secondary building units (SBUs) in a predetermined fashion to produce target network-based materials with specific structures and properties. In this regard, even the minor structural change of ligand such as the angle, distance, and relative orientation of the donor or functional groups can result in the variation of coordination framework.

elements.content: Recently, coordination polymers constructed by bent N-donor ligands of five-membered ring backbone such as 4-amino-3,5-bis(n-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole (bpt, n = 3 or 4), and 2,5-bis(n-pyridyl)-1,3,4-oxadiazole (bpo, n = 3 or 4) have been widely reported. However, coordination polymers based on carboxylic acid ligands such as 3,5-bis(3-carboxyphenyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-trizole (L1) are seldom reported. L1 was chosen as our ligand because it can form different conformations when phenyl cycles spin along C−C bond between pyridyl cycles and triazole cycles which have the similar features with the 4-amino-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole ligand in our previous work. The changes in conformations may result in the diverse structural topologies of coordination polymers based on different metal ions or SBUs.

However, coordination polymers based on carboxylic acid ligands such as 3,5-bis(3-carboxyphenyl)-4-amino-1,2,4-trizole (L1) are seldom reported. L1 was chosen as our ligand because it can form different conformations when phenyl cycles spin along C-C bond between pyridyl cycles and triazole cycles which have the similar features with the 4-amino-3,5-bis(3-pyridyl)-1,2,4-triazole ligand in our previous work. The changes in conformations may result in the diverse structural topologies of coordination polymers based on different metal ions or SBUs.

elements.content: Organic bases have been found to play different roles in the formation of various structural topologies, including being the agent to adjust pH or deprotonate O-donor ligands, structure-directing agent or template, and ligand to adjust the structure of coordination polymers. In this study, we selected different organic bases such as Et3N, 1,4-diazabicyclo[2.2.2]octane (DABCO), 4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy), 1,3-bi(4-pyridyl)propane (bpp), 1,4-bis(imidazol)butane (bib) as structure-directing agent or ligands to adjust the structure of coordination polymers. Ten coordination polymers have been successfully prepared and characterized by using L1 as spacers and transition metal ions as metal centers with adjusting role of different organic bases. Structural analysis of these coordination polymers reveals that the coordination polymers exhibit various topological structures. In addition, the magnetic and luminescent properties of the coordination polymers have also been investigated in the solid state.

In addition, the magnetic and luminescent properties of the coordination polymers have also been investigated in the solid state.

elements.content: All reagents and solvents were commercially available except for L1 and bib which were synthesized according to the literature. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellet. Fluorescent emission spectra for the solid samples were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer LS 55 luminescence spectrometer. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were obtained with SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design, MPMS-5) in the temperature range 2−300 K by using an applied field of 1000 Oe. Pascal’s constants were used to estimate the diamagnetic corrections, which were subtracted from the experimental susceptibility to give the molar paramagnetic susceptibility (χm).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All reagents and solvents were commercially available except for L1 and bib which were synthesized according to the literature. Elemental analyses were performed on a Perkin-Elmer 2400 element analyzer. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet Impact 410 FTIR spectrometer using KBr pellet. Fluorescent emission spectra for the solid samples were recorded on a Perkin-Elmer LS 55 luminescence spectrometer. Variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility data were obtained with SQUID magnetometer (Quantum Design, MPMS-5) in the temperature range 2-300 K by using an applied field of 1000 Oe. Pascal's constants were used to estimate the diamagnetic corrections, which were subtracted from the experimental susceptibility to give the molar paramagnetic susceptibility (χm).

elements.content: A mixture of L1 (0.040 g, 0.12 mmol), bib (0.022 g, 0.12 mmol), Mn(OAC)2 (0.037 g, 0.15 mmol), H2O (5 mL) was heated in a 20 mL Teflon-lined autoclave at 160 °C for 3 days, followed by slow cooling (5 °C·h−1) to room temperature. The resulting mixture was washed with water, and colorless block crystals were collected and dried in air. Yield: 35% (based on Mn). Elemental analysis (%): Calcd for 1 C 44.07, H 3.56, N 12.85; Found C 44.32, H 3.48, N 12.94. IR (KBr, cm−1): 3349(s), 1914(w), 1627(s), 1560(s), 906(m), 774(s), 717(s).

elements.content: The data collection and structural analysis of crystals 1−3, 5−8, and 10 were performed on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID equipped with a narrow-focus, 5.4 kW sealed tube X-ray source (graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). The data processing was accomplished with the PROCESS-AUTO processing program. The data collection and structural analysis of crystals 4 and 9 were performed on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator. The SMART software was used for data collection, for indexing the reflections and for determining the unit cell parameters; the collected data were integrated by using the SAINT software. All data were collected at a temperature of 20 ± 2 °C. Direct methods were used to solve the structure using the SHELXL crystallographic software package. All nonhydrogen atoms were easily found from the difference Fourier map. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in Table .
elements.clean_text:
X-Ray Structure Determinations

The data collection and structural analysis of crystals 1-3, 5-8, and 10 were performed on a Rigaku RAXIS-RAPID equipped with a narrow-focus, 5.4 kW sealed tube X-ray source (graphite-monochromated Mo Kα radiation, λ = 0.71073 Å). The data processing was accomplished with the PROCESS-AUTO processing program. The data collection and structural analysis of crystals 4 and 9 were performed on a Bruker SMART CCD diffractometer equipped with a graphite monochromator. The SMART software was used for data collection, for indexing the reflections and for determining the unit cell parameters; the collected data were integrated by using the SAINT software. All data were collected at a temperature of 20 ± 2 °C. Direct methods were used to solve the structure using the SHELXL crystallographic software package. All nonhydrogen atoms were easily found from the difference Fourier map. All non-hydrogen atoms were refined anisotropically. Basic information pertaining to crystal parameters and structure refinement is summarized in Table .

The asymmetric unit of crystal 1 consists of four and a half Mn(II) atoms, four L1 molecules, one hydroxyl group oxygen atom, six coordinated water molecules, and four and a half uncoordinated water molecules. As shown in Figure a, all Mn(II) atoms in crystal 1 are octahedral configurations. Mn1 is coordinated by four water molecules and two carboxyl group oxygen atoms (Mn−O = 2.164−2.223 Å); Mn2 is a distorted octahedral sphere consisting of six carboxyl group oxygen atoms from five different L1 molecules (Mn−O = 2.089−2.414 Å); the six coordination sites of Mn3 are occupied by five carboxyl group oxygen atoms of five L1 molecules and one hydroxyl group oxygen atom (Mn−O = 2.082−2.510 Å); Mn4 is also in a distorted octahedral environment built by three carboxyl group oxygen atoms of two L1 molecules, one hydroxyl group oxygen atom, and two water molecules (Mn−O = 2.069−2.646 Å); Mn5 is coordinated by three carboxyl group oxygen atoms from three L1 molecules, one hydroxyl group oxygen atom, and two water molecules (Mn−O = 2.111−2.245 Å). These Mn(II) atoms are interconnected by hydroxyl group oxygen atoms and carboxyl group to form a Mn4.5 unit which further links its symmetric part through four L1 molecules (cisoid-I) (Scheme ) to construct a Mn9 cluster (Figure b). To the best of our knowledge, the Mn9 cluster like this is rare. The structure of crystal 1 is constructed based on Mn9 clusters. Each Mn9 cluster links four identical Mn9 clusters around it through eight L1 molecules with cisoid-I and transoid-I (Scheme ) to construct a 3D net with diamond topology (Figure c, d). The uncoordinated water molecules fill the pore through hydrogen bond interactions.

These Mn(II) atoms are interconnected by hydroxyl group oxygen atoms and carboxyl group to form a Mn4.5 unit which further links its symmetric part through four L1 molecules (cisoid-I) (Scheme ) to construct a Mn9 cluster (Figure b). To the best of our knowledge, the Mn9 cluster like this is rare. The structure of crystal 1 is constructed based on Mn9 clusters. Each Mn9 cluster links four identical Mn9 clusters around it through eight L1 molecules with cisoid-I and transoid-I (Scheme ) to construct a 3D net with diamond topology (Figure c, d). elements.content: The asymmetric unit of crystal 2 includes three and a half Mn(II) atoms, three L1 molecules, one hydroxyl group oxygen atom and some coordinated and uncoordinated water molecules. As shown in Figure a, Mn1 is octahedral configurations coordinated by two carboxyl group oxygen atoms from two different L1 molecules, one hydroxyl group oxygen atom, and three water molecules; Mn2 is also octahedral sphere including three carboxyl group oxygen atoms of three L1 ligands, one hydroxyl group oxygen atom, and two water molecules; Mn3 is a tetragonal pyramidal configuration coordinated by four carboxyl group oxygen atoms of L1 ligands and one hydroxyl group oxygen atom. The three Mn(II) atoms are bridged by hydroxyl group oxygen atom and carboxyl group oxygen atoms to form a Mn3 cluster. Four L1 ligands including cisoid-I and cisoid-II modes link two Mn3 clusters to construct a cage (Figure b). Mn4 is octahedral sphere coordinated by six water molecules to form a free [Mn(H2O)6]2+ unit which fills in the cage. Adjacent cages are interconnected by L1 ligands with transoid-II mode to construct a 1D chain (Figure c). The 3D supermolecular structure of crystal 2 is constructed by intermolecule weak interactions between adjacent chains.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of crystal 3 includes one Cu(II) atom, one L1 molecule, and some uncoordinated water molecules. Two adjacent Cu(II) atoms are bridged by carboxyl group to form a paddle-wheel SBU. Each paddle-wheel SBU links four adjacent SBUs to construct a 2D layer (Figure a). Two adjacent 2D layers interweave each other through linkage of Ntriazole atoms to axial sites of paddle-wheel SBUs, constructing a 2D double-layer structure (Figure b). In crystal 3, L1 exhibits transoid-III coordination mode (Scheme ). If the paddle-wheel SBU is viewed as a node, the L1 will be a three-connected spacer and crystal 3 exhibits a unique {42.6}2{44.69.82} topology (Figure c). The 3D structure is constructed by weak interactions between two adjacent layers. The free water molecules are stabilized in the structure through H-bond interactions (Figure S1, ).

Each paddle-wheel SBU links four adjacent SBUs to construct a 2D layer (Figure a). elements.content: The asymmetric unit of crystal 4 contains one Zn(II) atom, one L1 molecule, one DMF molecule, and a quarter of (CH3)2NH molecule. Zn(II) atom is tetrahedral coordination sphere coordinated by two carboxyl group oxygen atoms of L1 (Zn−O = 1.920−1.945 Å), one Ntriazole atom (Zn−N = 2.034 Å), and one DMF molecule (Zn−O = 2.022 Å) (Figure a). Adjacent Zn(II) atoms are linked by L1 with carboxyl groups to form a 1D chain along a axis direction. Two adjacent 1D chains are interconnected through Ntriazole atoms to form a 1D double chain (Figure b). L1 molecules exhibit cisoid-III coordination mode here. DMF molecules as coordination terminal limit the dimensionality of coordination polymers. Free (CH3)2NH molecules formed by hydrolysis of DMF are filled in the structure through weak interactions. Each double chain is enclosed by six identical double chains and a 3D supramolecular structure is built by intermolecule weak interactions (Figure c).

Adjacent Zn(II) atoms are linked by L1 with carboxyl groups to form a 1D chain along a axis direction. elements.content: According to the structural features of crystal 4, we attempt to replace the terminal DMF molecule with bridging 4,4′-bipy ligand, which will result in coordination polymers with higher dimensionality. Single crystal X-ray diffraction analysis reveals that the asymmetric unit of crystal 5 consists of one Zn(II) atom, one L1 molecule, half of a 4,4′-bipy molecule, a quarter of free DMF and a quarter of free water molecule. Zn(II) atom is tetrahedral coordination sphere coordinated by two carboxyl group oxygen atoms (Zn−O = 1.947−1.985 Å) of two different L1 molecules, one Ntriazole atom (Zn−N = 2.038 Å) of another L1 molecule, and one nitrogen atom (Zn−N = 2.097 Å) of 4,4′-bipy (Figure a). Similar to crystal 4, crystal 5 also exhibits a similar 1D double chain structure through linking Zn(II) atoms by L1 (Figure S2, ). As we expected, 4,4-bipy in crystal 5 replace terminal DMF molecules of crystal 4 and link adjacent double chains to form a 2D double layer structure along the ab plane (Figure b). The 2D layer contains approximate (12.5 × 14.5 Å) pore when it is viewed along the c direction. From the view of topology, we select Zn(II) atom as four-connected node, and crystal 5 presents a unique V2O5 net. Its point (Schlafli) symbol for net: {42.63.8}{42.6} (Figure c). Two adjacent layers are packed together to construct a 3D supermolecular structure by intermolecule weak interactions (Figure S3, ). The free water molecules are stabilized in the structure through H-bond interactions.

The 2D layer contains approximate (12.5 × 14.5 Å) pore when it is viewed along the c direction. elements.content: Encouraged by the successful preparation of crystal 5, we selected bib as a new organic base to construct coordination polymers because bib have greater length and flexibility than 4,4′-bipy. The asymmetric unit of crystal 6 consists of two Zn(II) atoms, two L1 molecules, two half bib molecules, and some water molecules. Zn(II) atoms are all tetrahedral configurations coordinated by two carboxyl group oxygen atoms of two L1 (Zn−O = 1.921−1.965 Å), one Ntriazole atom of L1 (Zn−N = 2.026−2.057 Å), and one nitrogen atom (Zn−N = 1.994−2.002 Å) of bib (Figure a). Similar to crystals 4 and 5, L1 also links Zn(II) atoms to construct a double chain structure (Figure S4, ). The adjacent double chains are interconnected by bib (conformation I) (Figure a) to form a 2D layer (Figure b). The 3D structure of crystal 6 is built through bib molecule (conformation II) (Figure a) linking the adjacent 2D layers (Figure c). The free water molecules are filled in the structure through H-bond interactions. We choose the metal atoms as nodes, L1 and bib as spacers which link nodes to construct a rare coe topology (Figure d). Its point (Schlafli) symbol for net: {42.6.102.12}{42.6}.

The 3D structure of crystal 6 is built through bib molecule (conformation II) (Figure a) linking the adjacent 2D layers (Figure c). The free water molecules are filled in the structure through H-bond interactions. elements.content: The asymmetric unit of crystal 7 includes two Cd(II) atoms, two L1 molecules, three coordinated water molecules, and four and a half free water molecules. Cd1 is a distorted square bipyramid sphere coordinated by four oxygen atoms (Cd−O = 2.242−2.699 Å) from two L1 molecules and two Ntriazole atoms (Cd−N = 2.246−2.248 Å) of L1; while Cd2 is coordinated by four carboxyl group oxygen atoms of two L1 and three coordinated water molecules (Cd−O = 2.272−2.494 Å) to form a pentagonal bipyramid coordination configuration (Figure a). The two Cd(II) atoms are linked by four carboxyl groups of two L1 molecules (cisoid-IV) to form a circle shaped structure. Each circle links two adjacent circles through Ntriazole atoms bonding to Cd1 atoms to form an unusual 1D strap shaped structure along the c direction (Figure b). The free water molecules are filled in the structure through H-bond interactions. The 3D supermolecular structure is constructed by weak intermolecular interactions (Figure S5, ).

The two Cd(II) atoms are linked by four carboxyl groups of two L1 molecules (cisoid-IV) to form a circle shaped structure. elements.content: The asymmetric unit of crystal 8 includes one Cd(II) atom, one L1 ligand, three coordinated water molecules and some uncoordinated water molecules (Figure ). The Cd(II) atom is pentagonal bipyramid configuration consisting of four carboxyl group oxygen atoms of two L1 ligands and three coordinated water molecules. Two adjacent Cd(II) atoms are linked by L1 ligands with cisoid-VI mode to form a circle shaped structure similar to crystal 7. But differ from crystal 7, the Ntriazole atom of L1 ligand does not coordinate to Cd(II) atom. Therefore, crystal 8 is zero-periodic structure and its 3D supermolecular structure is constructed by weak intermolecular interactions.

Structure of [Cd(L1)(H2O)6.25] n  (8)

The asymmetric unit of crystal 8 includes one Cd(II) atom, one L1 ligand, three coordinated water molecules and some uncoordinated water molecules (Figure ). The Cd(II) atom is pentagonal bipyramid configuration consisting of four carboxyl group oxygen atoms of two L1 ligands and three coordinated water molecules. Two adjacent Cd(II) atoms are linked by L1 ligands with cisoid-VI mode to form a circle shaped structure similar to crystal 7. But differ from crystal 7, the Ntriazole atom of L1 ligand does not coordinate to Cd(II) atom. Therefore, crystal 8 is zero-periodic structure and its 3D supermolecular structure is constructed by weak intermolecular interactions.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of crystal 9 consists of one Cd(II) atom, one L1 molecule, and one bpp molecule. Cd(II) atom is a distorted square bipyramid sphere including four oxygen atoms of two L1 ligands (Cd−O = 2.284−2.527 Å), and two nitrogen atoms (Cd−N = 2.307−2.322 Å) of bpp (Figure a). L1 molecules link Cd(II) atoms to form a 1D zigzag chain along the b axis direction (Figure b). Two adjacent zigzag chains are interconnected through bpp to construct a 2D wave shaped layer along the ab plane (Figure c). The L1 molecules in crystal 9 show transoid-V coordination mode. It is interesting that each 2D layer is interweaved by two other identical layers (Figure d). From the view of topology, crystal 9 presents a 4-connected sql topology (Figure e). The point (Schlafli) symbol for net is {44.62}. Hydrogen bonding and π−π stacking interactions are both found in the structure as the main action force between two layers.

elements.content: The asymmetric unit of crystal 10 contains one Cd(II) atom, one L1 molecule, half of a bib molecule, one coordinated water molecule, and two free water molecules. The Cd(II) is a pentagonal bipyramid coordination sphere including five oxygen atoms from three different (Cd−O = 2.319−2.523 Å) L1 molecules, one nitrogen atom of bib (Cd−N = 2.282 Å), and one coordinated water molecule (Cd−O = 2.289 Å) (Figure a). Two Cd(II) atoms are linked by carboxyl group to form a Cd2 SBU. Each Cd2 cluster links two adjacent Cd2 clusters through four L1 molecules with cisoid-VII mode to form a 1D chain along the c axis direction (Figure b). Two 1D chains are interconnected by nitrogen atoms of bib bonding to the axis sites of 1D chain to construct a 1D strap shaped structure (Figure c). It looks like “H” when it is viewed from the c axis direction. The free water molecules are filled in the structure through H-bond interactions. Strong hydrogen bonding and π−π stacking interactions are found in the structure as the main action force to form 3D supermolecular net (Figure S6, ).

elements.content: Because L1 ligand tends to form different conformations as illustrated in introduction, we try to adjust the structures of coordination polymers using different conditions. For these compounds, Mn2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, and Cd2+ were chosen as metal sources, it is clearly that different metal ions will result in different structures of coordination polymers which can be seen from the above structures. These compounds were synthesized under two different solvent environments including water and DMF. Different solvents can influence the terminal structures of coordination polymers. For example, we use H2O to replace the DMF for compounds 4 and 5 and we cannot get the same phases which may due to different polarity and solubility of two solvents. For compounds 1, 3, 4, and 7, although organic bases were added in reaction process, they are not involved in the terminal structures. To confirm whether these organic bases could influence the structures of coordination polymers or not, experiments of comparison were done. For compound 1, we got compound 2 with different structures if corresponding organic base was not added. For 3, 4, and 7, we get the similar conclusion. Therefore, organic bases in these compounds may play the role of adjusting structures of coordination polymers as structure-directing agent or pH adjusting agent in the reaction process. Compared with others compounds, 3−5, and 7 used Cl− or NO3 − anions, respectively. In order to know whether anions will also influence the structures of coordination polymers, we replaced the Cl or NO3 − anions with OAC− anions in reaction process. For 7, we get a new compound 8 by using different anions. For compounds 3−5, using different anions will also obtain different phases similar to 7. It may due to the templating role of anions. In summary, the change of solvent, metallic ions, anions, and organic bases etc. would influence the structures of coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis

Because L1 ligand tends to form different conformations as illustrated in introduction, we try to adjust the structures of coordination polymers using different conditions. For these compounds, Mn2+, Cu2+, Zn2+, and Cd2+ were chosen as metal sources, it is clearly that different metal ions will result in different structures of coordination polymers which can be seen from the above structures. These compounds were synthesized under two different solvent environments including water and DMF. Different solvents can influence the terminal structures of coordination polymers. For example, we use H2O to replace the DMF for compounds 4 and 5 and we cannot get the same phases which may due to different polarity and solubility of two solvents. For compounds 1, 3, 4, and 7, although organic bases were added in reaction process, they are not involved in the terminal structures. To confirm whether these organic bases could influence the structures of coordination polymers or not, experiments of comparison were done. For compound 1, we got compound 2 with different structures if corresponding organic base was not added. For 3, 4, and 7, we get the similar conclusion. Therefore, organic bases in these compounds may play the role of adjusting structures of coordination polymers as structure-directing agent or pH adjusting agent in the reaction process. Compared with others compounds, 3-5, and 7 used Cl- or NO3 - anions, respectively. In order to know whether anions will also influence the structures of coordination polymers, we replaced the Cl or NO3 - anions with OAC- anions in reaction process. For 7, we get a new compound 8 by using different anions. For compounds 3-5, using different anions will also obtain different phases similar to 7. It may due to the templating role of anions. In summary, the change of solvent, metallic ions, anions, and organic bases etc. would influence the structures of coordination polymers.

elements.content: As can be seen from Scheme , L1 exhibits more coordination modes than 3-bpt, which mainly due to the diverse coordination modes of carboxyl groups. These coordination modes of carboxyl group can link metal ions to form sorts of SBUs, which favor to different structures of coordination polymers. In addition, L1 ligand can lose hydrogen proton forming L12- ligand. Therefore, it does not need additional anion to balance the charge of coordination polymers compared with coordination polymers based on N-donor ligand 3-bpt. Meantime, Ntriazole atom can coordinate to metal atom to form tridentate ligand. We studied the structural parameter of coordination polymers based on 3-bpt and L1 as tridentate ligands, and found that the dihedral between triazole cycle and phenyl cycle neighboring coordination Ntriazole atom should surpass 43°. Compared with coordination polymers based on 3-bpo, the amino group of L1 ligand can form hydrogen bond as H-donor which can influence the structure of coordination polymers.
elements.clean_text:
Compared Coordination Polymers based on L1 with 3-bpt and 3-bpo

As can be seen from Scheme , L1 exhibits more coordination modes than 3-bpt, which mainly due to the diverse coordination modes of carboxyl groups. These coordination modes of carboxyl group can link metal ions to form sorts of SBUs, which favor to different structures of coordination polymers. In addition, L1 ligand can lose hydrogen proton forming L12- ligand. Therefore, it does not need additional anion to balance the charge of coordination polymers compared with coordination polymers based on N-donor ligand 3-bpt. Meantime, Ntriazole atom can coordinate to metal atom to form tridentate ligand. We studied the structural parameter of coordination polymers based on 3-bpt and L1 as tridentate ligands, and found that the dihedral between triazole cycle and phenyl cycle neighboring coordination Ntriazole atom should surpass 43°. Compared with coordination polymers based on 3-bpo, the amino group of L1 ligand can form hydrogen bond as H-donor which can influence the structure of coordination polymers.

elements.content: The photoluminescent properties of compounds 4−7, 9 and the free ligand (L1) have been studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the emissions are observed at 469 nm for 4 when excited at 314 nm. Compound 5 displays emission maxima at 482 when excitated at 336 nm. Compound 6 shows an emission band located at 468 and 474 nm with excitation wavelength of 320 nm. Upon excitation at 328 nm, emission is obtained at 476 nm for 7. Compound 9 exhibits an emission band at 470 nm with excitation wavelength of 330 nm. The free ligand (L1) exhibits emission maximum at 421 nm upon excitation at 330 nm. The emissions of coordination polymers can be due to the intraligand charge transfer (ILCT) of organic ligands. The difference in their emissions and excitations is probably due to the differences in metal ions and coordination environment around them, because photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the local environments around metal ions. These observations suggest that these compounds can serve as candidates for potential photoactive materials.
elements.clean_text:
Photoluminescent Properties

The photoluminescent properties of compounds 4-7, 9 and the free ligand (L1) have been studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the emissions are observed at 469 nm for 4 when excited at 314 nm. Compound 5 displays emission maxima at 482 when excitated at 336 nm. Compound 6 shows an emission band located at 468 and 474 nm with excitation wavelength of 320 nm. Upon excitation at 328 nm, emission is obtained at 476 nm for 7. Compound 9 exhibits an emission band at 470 nm with excitation wavelength of 330 nm. The free ligand (L1) exhibits emission maximum at 421 nm upon excitation at 330 nm. The emissions of coordination polymers can be due to the intraligand charge transfer (ILCT) of organic ligands. The difference in their emissions and excitations is probably due to the differences in metal ions and coordination environment around them, because photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the local environments around metal ions. These observations suggest that these compounds can serve as candidates for potential photoactive materials.

elements.content: Variable temperature d.c. magnetic susceptibility data were collected on powdered microcrystalline samples of crystal 1 in the 2−300 K temperature range in a 0.1 T applied external magnetic field. There is a gradual decrease in χM T value from 300 to 100 K for 1 (Figure ). Below this temperature χM T value falls very sharply. This indicates an antiferromagnetic interaction is domintant within the molecule. The χM T value at room temperature (33.05 cm3 K mol−1) is considerably below the expected spin-only value for nine bivalent uncorrelated spins (39.38 cm3 K mol−1). This reduction implies that an intramolecular antiferromagnetic interaction is dominant. The large negative θ value (−26.61 K) obtained from the plot of inverse susceptibility as a function of temperature above 100 K also supports our conclusion. We also measured the a.c. magnetic susceptibility of compound 1, and a.c. magnetic susceptibility has no singnal.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic Properties

Variable temperature d.c. magnetic susceptibility data were collected on powdered microcrystalline samples of crystal 1 in the 2-300 K temperature range in a 0.1 T applied external magnetic field. There is a gradual decrease in χM T value from 300 to 100 K for 1 (Figure ). Below this temperature χM T value falls very sharply. This indicates an antiferromagnetic interaction is domintant within the molecule. The χM T value at room temperature (33.05 cm3Kmol-1) is considerably below the expected spin-only value for nine bivalent uncorrelated spins (39.38 cm3K mol-1). This reduction implies that an intramolecular antiferromagnetic interaction is dominant. The large negative θ value (-26.61 K) obtained from the plot of inverse susceptibility as a function of temperature above 100 K also supports our conclusion. We also measured the a.c. magnetic susceptibility of compound 1, and a.c. magnetic susceptibility has no singnal.

elements.content: Eight new coordination polymers exhibiting 1D to 3D structures have been synthesized by using L1 as ligand and by adjusting the roles of different organic bases. Diverse architectures and other interesting features of these compounds are also found, such as interpenetration, different dimensional framework and molecular topology, as well as weak interactions including hydrogen bonding, π−π stacking interactions, etc. The structural differences show that the ligand, the metal center, and organic bases have great influence on the structure of the final assembly. The luminescent properties of compounds 4−7, and 9 indicate that they may be good candidates for luminescent materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

Eight new coordination polymers exhibiting 1D to 3D structures have been synthesized by using L1 as ligand and by adjusting the roles of different organic bases. Diverse architectures and other interesting features of these compounds are also found, such as interpenetration, different dimensional framework and molecular topology, as well as weak interactions including hydrogen bonding, π-π stacking interactions, etc. The structural differences show that the ligand, the metal center, and organic bases have great influence on the structure of the final assembly. The luminescent properties of compounds 4-7, and 9 indicate that they may be good candidates for luminescent materials.

cln_elements.content:
The photoluminescent properties of compounds 4−7, 9 and the free ligand (L1) have been studied in the solid state at room temperature. As shown in Figure , the emissions are observed at 469 nm for 4 when excited at 314 nm. Compound 5 displays emission maxima at 482 when excitated at 336 nm. Compound 6 shows an emission band located at 468 and 474 nm with excitation wavelength of 320 nm. Upon excitation at 328 nm, emission is obtained at 476 nm for 7. Compound 9 exhibits an emission band at 470 nm with excitation wavelength of 330 nm. The free ligand (L1) exhibits emission maximum at 421 nm upon excitation at 330 nm. The emissions of coordination polymers can be due to the intraligand charge transfer (ILCT) of organic ligands. The difference in their emissions and excitations is probably due to the differences in metal ions and coordination environment around them, because photoluminescence behavior is closely associated with the local environments around metal ions. These observations suggest that these compounds can serve as candidates for potential photoactive materials.

Magnetic Properties

Variable temperature d.c. magnetic susceptibility data were collected on powdered microcrystalline samples of crystal 1 in the 2−300 K temperature range in a 0.1 T applied external magnetic field. There is a gradual decrease in χM T value from 300 to 100 K for 1 (Figure ). Below this temperature χM T value falls very sharply. This indicates an antiferromagnetic interaction is domintant within the molecule. The χM T value at room temperature (33.05 cm3 K mol−1) is considerably below the expected spin-only value for nine bivalent uncorrelated spins (39.38 cm3 K mol−1). This reduction implies that an intramolecular antiferromagnetic interaction is dominant. The large negative θ value (−26.61 K) obtained from the plot of inverse susceptibility as a function of temperature above 100 K also supports our conclusion. We also measured the a.c. magnetic susceptibility of compound 1, and a.c. magnetic susceptibility has no singnal.
